ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Hydrothermal synthesis of 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures; lattice vibrations and novel photoluminescence properties

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Physics, School of Mathematics and Physics
Affiliation.OrgName: University of Science and Technology Beijing

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Center for Advanced Mathematics and Physics
Affiliation.OrgName: National University of Science and Technology (NUST)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper, Novel 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanoarchitectures self-assembled by interconnecting densely stacked nanosheets have been successfully synthesized by facile hydrothermal growth method. The crystalline phase, morphology, particle size and component of the as-prepared nanomaterial were characterized by X-ray diffraction, field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy. FESEM analysis shows that the size of 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures is in the range of 1–1.5 μm, and the thickness of interconnected nanosheets is about 45 nm on the average. The structural features of as-synthesized Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures are studied to analyze the near-neighbor environment of oxygen coordination around manganese and copper cations reported for the first time using Raman scattering spectroscopy. Moreover, the novel photoluminescence spectra of the as-prepared Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures are reported exhibiting prominent emission bands located in red-violet spectral region.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Nanoscale transition metal oxides have been attracting an immense attention because of their inimitable electrical, optical and magnetic properties [1]. Recently delafossite-type oxides, such as ATMO2 with TM = transition metal and A = monovalent element (Cu, Ag or Na), have caught a great interest of the researchers. Among this family, CuTMO2 due to its thermoelectric [2] and multiferroic properties [3] has achieved immense attraction. The crystal structure of CuTMO2 is usually hexagonal delafossite in which monovalent Cu cations are linearly coordinated with two O2 anions and the parallel chains of O–Cu–O are connected to TM3+ cations forming two-dimensional sheets of edge-sharing TMO6 octahedrons [4]. Accordingly, CuTMO2 is regarded as composed of two layers; one TM oxide magnetic layer and the other cuprous oxide semiconducting layer. Therefore, a strong coupling between spin and exciton is expected in CuTMO2 [5]. It is generally believed that the absorption peak of TM oxides gets into visible region by the incorporation of photochemically active compound [6, 7]. Copper (Cu) is a well-known plasmonic (optical) material that, when combined with a magnetic material such as Manganese (Mn), can result in a system with excellent magneto-optical properties [8].The future technologies are exploring cost-effective and facile methods for the fabrication of one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) nanomaterials [1]. 1D and 2D nanomaterials exhibit special properties such as efficient transport of electrons and optical excitations and are vital to the function and integration of nanoscale devices [9]. Compared to 1D and 2D nanostructures, 3D nanoarchitectures possibly possess more distinctive chemical and physical properties due to their novel structures [10].

Only few research ventures have been put together to synthesize Cu@Mn3O4 [8], CuxMn3−xO4 [11], CuMnO2 [4], Cu1.4Mn1.6O4 [5] and Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 [12]. Recently, we have reported the hydrothermal synthesis of 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanowhiskers and their photoluminescent response in the green-violet spectral region [13].However, there is a lack of information on the mechanism of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 vibrational characteristics at the bulk and nanoscale level. Therefore, the exploration of the mechanism of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructural behaviors and their characteristic photoluminescence in detail still remains a major challenge. The hydrothermal growth method is the most common and useful approach for the preparation of thermodynamically stable compounds. The main advantage of hydrothermal method over other chemical routes is that the nanoscopic morphologies can be controlled by varying reaction parameters in the system, such as control of reaction temperature, dwell time, change of pH value and choices of solvents [13–18].

Here, we demonstrate the hydrothermal approach to fabricate 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanoarchitectures, their detailed structural characterizations and novel photoluminescence (PL) emission properties. Furthermore, the vibrational features of the as-prepared nanostructured Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 are reported for the first time using Raman spectroscopy.

Section2.Heading: Sample preparation
Section2.Para: Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures were synthesized by a simple hydrothermal route. All reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. In a typical procedure, 1 g of KMnO4 was added to 40 ml of deionized water and magnetically stirred for 20 min. While stirring, 1 g of CuO and 1.5 g of KOH were added and stirred ultrasonically for another 20 min. The resultant solution was calcined in a stainless autoclave at 180 °C for 24 h under constant pressure. The autoclave was allowed to cool down at room temperature. After completion of the reaction, the prepared product was washed with distill water several times, filtered, centrifuged, dried at 90 °C for 6 h and finally collected for further characterization.

Section2.Heading: Sample characterizations
Section2.Para: The initial morphology and composition of the resultant product were studied by field-emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-3500-SEM) operated at 15 kV and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (Hitachi S-3500-EDX) using 32 eV beam resolution from 100 to 500 cps. Crystallinity and phase of the as-prepared nanostructures were investigated by X-ray diffractometer (X’Pert MPD-XRD) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Raman spectroscopy (Horiba Jobin–Yvon HR 800 Raman spectrometer with 532 nm wavelength excitation) was performed to investigate the structural property of the synthesized nanomaterial. Photoluminescence (F-4500 FL Spectrophotometer) was employed to study the optical properties of the synthesized material.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussions
Section1.Para:
The morphology of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures was primarily investigated by FESEM as depicted in Fig. 1a, b. The low magnification FESEM images shown in Fig. 1a, b) demonstrate that most of the as-synthesized products are uniform and identical 3D flower-like nanostructures. A high magnification FESEM image in Fig. 1c reveals that flower-like Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 has architectures composed of self-assembled interconnecting nanosheets. It clearly shows that large arrays of densely stacked nanosheets aggregated together and self-assembled into 3D flower-type nanostructures. Close examination of the high magnification FESEM image Fig. 1d shows that all architectures have diameters ranging from 1 to 1.5 μm and the thickness of interconnected nanosheets is measured to be about 45 nm on the average.
Fig. 1
a–d Low and high magnification FESEM images of 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures e TEM image and f HRTEM image of a single nanosheet along with SAED pattern (lower inset)

More detailed information regarding the structural aspects of the as-prepared Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures has been investigated by TEM and HRTEM. A TEM image shown in Fig. 2e clearly suggests that the as-synthesized flower-like Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanoarchitectures are self-assembled with nanosheets, which is in agreement with the FESEM observations. The HRTEM image taken from a single nanosheet given in Fig. 1f shows the lattice fringes of the nanosheet with the single set of parallel planes, clearly displaying the single-crystalline nature. The interplanar spacing of fringes is measured to be about 0.232 nm which corresponds to the maximum diffraction peak in the XRD spectrum. The single-crystalline structure of as-prepared nanostructured Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 is also confirmed by the SAED pattern shown in the lower inset of Fig. 2f.
Fig. 2
a XRD patterns of as-prepared 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures and b an EDX spectrum

Figure 2a displays the XRD pattern of as-prepared nanostructured Cu0.45Mn0.55O2. All the diffraction peaks are consistent with the position and intensity and well indexed to the standard diffraction data as listed in (JCPDS file no. 41-0184). Sharp diffraction peaks indicate the good crystalline quality of the prepared product. No impurity peak is observed which indicates the high purity of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures. The average grain size was calculated to be about 40 nm using Debye–Scherrer formula. The EDS analysis illustrated in Fig. 2b manifests that the final product contains only Mn, Cu and O, which suggests that the synthesized nanostructures are made of pure Cu0.45Mn0.55O2. The elemental compositions of the as-prepared flower-like Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanoarchitectures are given in Table 1.
Table 1

Raman spectroscopy is a functional technique and relatively standard characterization tool for nanocrystalline materials giving detailed information on the crystal structure, composition and electronic states of nanostructures. Figure 3a shows the Raman spectrum of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures synthesized by hydrothermal route, in which there are five fundamental vibrational modes 630, 572, 471, 356 and 302 cm−1 corresponding to the skeletal vibrations. The scattering for all Raman modes was very strong particularly for 630 cm−1 mode, which indicates the presence of well-defined electronic states in the synthesized Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures. The two high-wavenumber vibrational modes observed at 630 and 572 cm−1 dominating the whole spectra can be attributed to the symmetric Mn–O stretching vibrations of MnO6 groups, while the bands in low-wavenumber region, which appears with a relatively weak intensity, correspond to Cu–O stretching vibrations. The broad peaks with less relative intensities observed at 471, 356 and 302 cm−1 reflect the phonon density of states rather than the Raman-allowed zone center phonons, which is due to the confinement of phonons by some crystal defects and local lattice distortions in the as-prepared Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures caused by small grains and point defects resulting in the decay of phonons and the breakdown in the Raman selection rules.
Fig. 3
a Raman spectrum and b room temperature photoluminescence spectra of as-prepared 3D flower-like Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanoarchitectures

Section2.Heading: Photoluminescence properties
Section2.Para: To determine the optical properties, we have investigated the photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of hydrothermally grown Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures. Figure 3b displays the PL emission spectrum of the as-synthesized material measured at room temperature with an excitation wavelength of 250 nm. Through the Gaussian curve fitting, five obvious emission peaks at 338, 391, 465, 535 and 639 nm were observed. Recently, the photoluminescence emissions in the violet-green spectral region of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanowhiskers have been reported [13]. Here, the emission peaks centered at 338 nm in the UV region and 639 nm in the red band have been observed in addition to the green-violet spectral region, simultaneously. The prominent UV and blue emissions are attributed to the radiative recombination and emission of free excitons and oxygen vacancy-related defects [13, 18], while a broad and weak green emission centered at 535 nm can be assigned to the surface dangling bonds or surface defects [13, 18] on the surface of nanosheets. The novel red PL emission located at 639 nm can be attributed to quantum confinement effect of the crystalline Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanoarchitectures, because the self-assembly of large amount of nanosheets into 3D flower-like Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 architectures can lead to abundant structural defects that activate the Jahn–Teller effect and the corresponding d–d transitions and consequently quantum confinement effect can occur [19] which contributes to the red PL emission. These conspicuous PL emission characteristics in the red-violet spectral region demonstrate the promise of the obtained Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures for practical applications such as for ultraviolet and visible light emission devices.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: To conclude, we have successfully synthesized 3D Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures self-assembled with interconnecting nanosheets by a facile hydrothermal growth method without using any templates. The flower-like Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 architectures have diameter in the range of 1–1.5 μm, and the crystalline size of nanosheets was estimated to be about 40 nm using Debye–Scherrer formula. The vibrational features of Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures have been reported for the first time using Raman scattering spectroscopy. The novel PL spectra of the as-prepared nanostructured Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 architectures exhibit prominent emission bands located in red-violet spectral region. In addition, a red PL emission was observed and attributed to the quantum confinement of crystalline Cu0.45Mn0.55O2 nanostructures. The photoluminescence studies indicate the promise of this material for potential applications in optoelectronic UV and visible emission devices.
